name: Jinteki Shell Game v3.0 (Hank Scorpio Edition)
description:
Place all ice on centrals with enigma on the outer layer. Install and rez ruhr valleys on centrals asap. Spend multiple turns installing large amounts of assets and agendas. Take all the bad pub in the world as long as you have a plan to remove it.

Rules to follow when playing the deck:

  1. Take bad pub... float credits.... be rich and loving it.
  2. Only ice the centrals.
  3. Never rez anything immediatly after installing (Except Ruhr Valley, this needs to be rezzed BEFORE the run is announced). Make them guess. Drives them nuts.
  4. Don't worry if they score... the amount of economy they just sacrificed for that one pointer is HILARIOUS.
  5. Every turn ask them how many cards they have in hand (scorch bluff).
  6. Every time you install something in a remote, pause, look them straight in the eye, and calmly announce that you are installing a snare. Cackle maniacally. Profit.

name: HB Modified Red Coats
description:
Took 3rd at Chronos Protocol Auckland 2 weeks ago, built around the Red Coats idea but I had to sub cards in and out because I didn't have all the datapacks (no Action Jackson! GASP) and Double Time was not tournament legal at the event.

Key idea was to overwhelm with asset econ and start fortifying centrals plus one remote server with more ice than you can shake a stick at. I found it interesting how people were keen to run face down remotes early and after they see 2 PADs they start ignoring them so it served as a hiding spot for agendas when I got agenda flooded or when they started trying to hit HQ.

Low agenda density kept runners wasting time hammering RnD, except for the one occasion on the final game where a Gabe runner hit RnD 3 times and got all the points he needed. High ice density played well with ABT and helped mitigate losing some of them to Noise runners. Assets worked well installed or no since people trash Ash wherever they see him anyway. Not sure about the shooters since they didn't really come into play at any point.

Think this is a little point to help prove that you don't need all the datapacks to remain competitive. Running a deck that only had up to CaC with no Jackson and not ending up rock bottom is not impossible.

name: Enjoy the Ads
20th Sentry Foxfire
Lady never hasty
description: A runner deck without program. She just wait, until she see an agenda, and then give a blackmall.

name: skittles
nothing to see here
Mo Money, Mo Programs
description:
This is my second deck, built based on what I learned using my first deck. My general plan is:

  • Lots of cards that give you little economic upticks (Professional Contacts & Magnum Opus for free money during your turn, Ice Analyzer for free money during your opponent's turn, and Aesop's Pawnshop & Freelance Coding Contract to trash unwanted cards for cash)

  • Those lovely Core Shaper icebreakers that stay pumped for the duration of the run, with Tinkering to spare you from having to pump a new icebreaker from scratch at critical moments (with Crypsis & Femme Fatale thrown in to provide broader options)

  • As many memory upgrades as possible, Lemuria Codecracker for scouting, Forged Activation Orders to screw with your opponent??

name: Can't Take My Ice Off You
description:
• Lots of options to increase number of clicks (Biotic Labour, Director Haas, Efficiency Committee, etc)

  • Small agendas intended to be installed and scored in a single turn (using all those extra clicks & SanSan City Grid).

  • Most out-of-faction card allowance used to beef up Ice coverage.

  • Rest of cards used to boost credit economy. (Also some Research Stations, because when is that ever a bad idea??)

  • Oh, and Cerebral Overwriter if you feel like setting a trap ;)

name: Slipstream
description: This deck is my best kept secret. It runs early (Kit's ability + SMC), is cost efficient (Datasucker + Cloak/Dagger), and cheap (most cards only cost 1 or 2 credits). It is resilient against program destruction, NBN has a hard time locking up R&D, and it avoids Jinteki damage with Indexing. Outpace the corp and win before they stabilize. Save your Parasites for big barriers, low strength sentries, or Tollbooth. Or just use them all and recur them with Levy AR. With proper piloting, you cannot lose.

name: CI - Ivory Tower
Andromeda - Hail to the queen.o8d
Who You Know.
description:
This is a Keyhole deck that leverages passive credits and connections. Get a Dyson in play then start spamming Underworld Contacts. Use every trick you can to get credits without spending clicks, with Tri-Mafs as a backup source of cash.

If you can get Keyhole out early, great. Otherwise get Logos asap.

Do NOT steal any agendas if it will give you more points than the corp! Just keep hammering at R&D with Keyhole and spamming connections. Calling in Favors will give you huge cash boosts late game.

name: The Famous Ken Tenma 0.2
Event: Make runs
description:
With prepaids you can frequently make a credit just from playing a run event (1 prepaid voicepad and early bird is a subliminal messaging!). They make sure gamble and dirty laundry really good too, while not being integral to success. 15 run events plus same old thing should be more than enough to give a return on your ID choice.

Never project which way you're focusing because you don't run RDI or HQI, instead, the events dictate your focus.

Breakers are cheap to install and sufficiently efficient, and they work on remotes. Can't wait for this ID the more I think about it.

name: Jinteki Net Damage Fun
Who You Know v1.2
description:
This is an old version of the deck design. Version 1.5 is linked in the comments below.

This is a Keyhole deck that leverages passive credits and connections. Get a Dyson or the Helpful AI in play then start spamming Underworld Contacts. Use every trick you can to get credits without spending clicks, with Tri-Mafs as a backup source of cash.

If you can get Keyhole out early, great. Otherwise get Logos asap.

Do NOT steal any agendas if it will give you more points than the corp! Just keep hammering at R&D with Keyhole and spamming connections. Calling in Favors will give you huge cash boosts late game.

name: First Corp Deck
Ain't nobody got time for that 1.2
description: Revised version (thanks Bubo). Tax the player for running at your remotes, and possibly end the run anyway with Caprice. Only a theory for now, will test run it as soon as possible.

name: NEXT Best Thing
Shadow of Doubt
description: hit hard and fast. Tear through your deck, keep the corp poor and dig.

name: Aggressive Dino Lover 1.2
description:
General Idea

I've always been an agressive player, running alot and keeping as much pressure as humanliy possible. This deck is custom built for that type of playstyle. Run early, run alot. Have the corp in it's toes, and eventually build up your rig and start digging.

The Cards

Many cards speak for themselves, but I will focus on some of the core mechanics and their cards.

Account Siphon and Indexing

These are the best cards to get early, I almost always keep my hand if I find both in my starting hand. Both cards puts high pressure on the corp. I usually start with a run on HQ, if rez, I index R&D, if the other way around, I Siphon their accounts. Some rush decks will stop both, centrals, but then you know early what kind of deck you are up against. A rule of thumb is to always Account Siphon on your second click, so you can remove the tags.

Self-modifying Code and Clone Chip

This combo has seen many plays before, so I am certain you are familiar with the tactic. Face check with SMC so that you can pull out any breaker you want (keep yourself over 5 credits, preferably around 10). Deus Ex gets rid of all the ice that hurts you (net and brain damage) and Sharpshooter prevents your precious programs from getting trashed.

Ice Breakers

Corroder is an auto include, not much to say there. Zu.13 is just really cheap and easy to pull with SMC. Femme Fatale is a real pain in the ass to hard install (paying full price), but her bypass have always paid out. Use Clone Chip to retrieve SMC (like mid-run even) or any of your ice-breakers.

Strategy

Run on your first click, if you get beaten up fine, nothing can kill you in the first turn. If you run into a neural katana, just jack out and draw some cards. As the game progresses, use the standard rule of thumb: Remotes -> HQ -> R&D -> Archives. But if you can, pressure the centrals with Siphon and Indexing. This locks down R&D (that is what this deck does best) and keeping the corp poor (and you filthy rich).

Good luck and have fun!

name: Helsinki Chronos Protocol 2nd place Corp Deck
description:
This is the deck I used at the Helsinki Chronos Protocol Tour on 20th of April 2014. I placed 2nd after 5 rounds of swiss. 4 wins and 1 loss as corp.

A couple of notes:

-Chimera wasn't very good. I regretted having it in hand in every game I drew it. Just wouldn't have enough money to use it or there was already an atman at 0 in play..

-The 1-of operations were really nice. Freelancer won me one game together with sansan'd breaking news. There's nothing as satisfying as getting rid of a 6-cred kati and pro-con. With 1 card & click. And for free. Corporate shuffle also saved a game after a mulligan into a bad start and Cyberdex Trial was useful in at least a couple of games.

-NAPD Contract is really nice. I scored it in almost every game the hard way, as runners just couldn't steal it when they went for it because of the steal cost.

-Data Raven wasn't very useful, though it might've put some fear of scorched combos and made runners cautious when they saw it in R&D or HQ.

I'd probably get rid of chimera and red herrings and put in some econ, maybe beanstalks or marked accounts or add one SfSS. I might also swap interns for archived memories for added flexibility.

name: Can't Stop the Signal
description:
TagMe Anarch! Keep them low on credits through Siphon, trashing your numerous resources, and (sometimes) purging virus counters. Takes practice to run, but very fun. 5 clicks is addictive. :)

Things I still want to try: Medium, Tallie Perault,

name: Kit - Paint me like one of your Android girls
description: Use paintbrush to make Torch more viable mid game. Pay with lockpicks. Hit R&D hard.

name: Kit - Paint me like one of your Android girls
Who You Know v1.3
description:
This deck has been updated to version 1.5. It can be found here.

netrunnerdb.com/en/decklist/4547/who-you-know-v1-5

This is a Keyhole deck that leverages passive credits and connections. Get a Dyson or the Helpful AI in play then start spamming Underworld Contacts. Use every trick you can to get credits without spending clicks, with Tri-Mafs as a backup source of cash.

If you can get Keyhole out early, great. Otherwise get Logos asap.

Try to keep your score just below the corps until your ready to end it. Keep hammering at R&D with Keyhole and spamming connections. If an opportunity to steal an agenda comes take it, then forfeit the agenda to the Data Dealer. Calling in Favors will give you huge cash boosts late game.

name: Noiseshop
Joshua B. Masanori and the Curious Case of the Data Leak Rev
description: My take on the Joshua B/Account Siphon/DLR deck that seems to be going around. Main thing I worry about is lack of face-checking power.

name: Collective
Doppelganger Whizzard
